children.subject: Yes, thanks for your note.  It's quite instructive.  I'll try to add a note at the bottom of the node to explain it as you suggest.  Thanks, Eric

Yes, $$(w,v) \in E$$ means there's an edge $$(w,v)$$ in the original graph.

Here's how I think about it: from the "perspective" of edge $$(w,v)$$ in the original graph, the edge $$(v,w)$$ is a back-edge, which we may add to $$G^f$$ with capacity $$c^f(vw)=f(wv)-d(wv)$$, the amount that we can reduce the flow along $$(w,v)$$ while still satisfying demand.

Similarly, from the "perspective" of edge $$(v,w)$$ in the original graph, the edge $$(v,w)$$ is a forward-edge, which we may add to $$G^f$$ with capacity $$c^f(vw)=c(vw)-f(vw)$$, the remaining capacity along  $$(v,w)$$.

Thanks for the note!

I am still confused by the expression $$if (w,v) \in E$$. Does it mean there is an edge goes from $$w$$ to $$v$$ in the original graph? Or there is an edge connecting $$(w,v) $$? 

EDIT: From the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm, it looks like we are keeping track of the back-edge in the original graph. If that is the case, then the expression $$if (w,v) \in E$$ makes sense.

history.content:
[This was a question that I figured out while typing it up. I figured I'd post it as a note in case it helps someone else]

In the regular max flow problem, we construct the residual network as follows:

- if $$(v,w) \in E$$ and $$f(vw) < c(vw)$$: add $$(v,w)$$ to $$E^f$$ with $$c^f(v,w)=c(vw)-f(vw)$$

- if $$(v,w) \in E$$ and $$f(vw) > 0$$: add $$(w,v)$$ to $$E^f$$ with $$c^f(w,v)=f(vw)$$

My guess was that in max feasible flow, we'd do essentially the same thing, but instead of setting the back-edges to  $$f(vw)$$, we'd set them to $$f(vw)-d(vw)$$, so that "zeroing out" a flow with a back-edge would still meet the demand:

- if $$(v,w) \in E$$ and $$f(vw) < c(vw)$$: add $$(v,w)$$ to $$E^f$$ with $$c^f(v,w)=c(vw)-f(vw)$$

- if $$(v,w) \in E$$ and $$f(vw) > d(vw)$$: add $$(w,v)$$ to $$E^f$$ with $$c^f(w,v)=f(vw)-d(vw)$$

But the lecture describes constructing the max feasible flow residual network as follows:

$$c^f(vw) = \left\{\begin{matrix} c(vw)-f(vw) & \text{ if } (v,w) \in E\\ f(wv)-d(wv) & \text{ if } (w,v) \in E\\ 0 & \text{otherwise}\\ \end{matrix}\right.$$

At first, this new format confused me. It seemed like we were no longer constructing back-edges since we conditioned on $$(w,v) \in E$$. Then I realized that the formula is setting $$c^f(vw)$$, which is the back-edge for $$(w,v) \in E$$ (and the forward edge for $$(v,w) \in E$$). So, the lecture formula and my "guessed" formula are saying the same thing after all.
history.subject: Constructing residual network for max feasible flow problem (MF5: Max Feasible Flow)
